Determine the formula for the sum of the first n-1 integers.
Determine the formula for the factorial of the first n-1 integers.
Simplify the sum to show it equals (n-1)n/2.
Simplify the factorial term to (n-1)!.
Set up the equation to check when (n-1)n/2 is a factor of (n-1)!.
Analyze the prime factorization properties of both sides of the equation.
Use properties of factorials and divisibility to simplify conditions for when (n-1)n/2 divides (n-1)!.
Analyze patterns or properties about prime number n, focusing on the required divisibility condition.
List down small prime numbers and check each against the divisibility condition.
Discuss whether the condition can be true for larger primes, considering the growth rate of factorial compared to the quadratic function.

Express the sum of the series from 1 to (n-1) mathematically.
Calculate the factorial of (n-1), which is the product of all integers from 1 to (n-1).
Set up the equation based on the problem statement: The sum 1+2+...+(n-1) is a factor of the factorial of (n-1).
Understand and simplify the expressions of the sum and the factorial in terms of n.

Analyze special cases by inputting smaller prime numbers and verifying the divisibility.
Identify a pattern or a mathematical property that relates the sum and factorial with prime numbers.
Generalize for all primes greater than 2 and prove or refute the hypothesis for each case.
Summarize the results and deduce a conclusion about prime numbers for which the divisibility holds.
